text: 3 Reproducible Reporting

title: 2¬† Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: References
text:
Knuth, Donald E. 1984. ‚ÄúLiterate Programming.‚Äù Comput.
J. 27 (2): 97‚Äì111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
2.1 Why Reproducibility Matters
Science builds on itself: - Verification of findings - Error detection and correction - Learning from previous work - Cumulative knowledge advancement
Without reproducibility ‚Üí No science

Reproducibility is not an add-on feature but the core mechanism that makes science self-correcting

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
2.2 The Reproducibility Problem
Current reality in research: - Core elements remain unpublished (data, code, materials) - Published articles alone cannot enable reproduction - Meta-scientific studies show low reproducibility rates - This fundamentally undermines cumulative science

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
2.3 What is Reproducibility?
Key distinction:




Same Data
Different Data




Same Analysis
Reproducible
Replicable


Different Analysis
Robust
Generalizable



Today‚Äôs focus: Making our work reproducible

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
2.4 Two Interconnected Practices

Reproducible Reporting

Document the complete analytical workflow
Make every step traceable and executable

FAIR Data Management

Ensure research products can be found and reused
Systematic framework for long-term accessibility

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
2.5 Reproducibility as Core Practice
Not an optional extra, but: - Enables scientific verification - Facilitates error detection - Allows learning from publications - Strengthens cumulative knowledge
Question: How do we make this practical?

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.1 The Current Problem
Example: ‚ÄúA confirmatory factor analysis provided evidence for the proposed two-dimensional structure (CFI = .956, TLI = .955, SRMR = .047)‚Äù
Can you reproduce this? - Which measurement model? - Which estimator? - How were missing values handled? - Where is the data?
‚Üí Impossible without code and data

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.2 Evidence: Reproducibility is Rare
Empirical studies show low reproducibility:

Add studies from repo comp-repro!!!


Psychology (Hardwicke et al.¬†2018, 2021): Difficulties reproducing published analyses even with open data
Economics (Chang & Li 2015): Problems reproducing results from published papers
Political Science (Eubank 2016): Challenges in replication attempts

Common barriers: Missing code, incomplete data documentation, unclear analytical steps

title: 2¬† Slides
section: 3.3 The Solution: Add Code and Data
text:
3.3 The Solution: Add Code and Data
Peng (2011): Publication becomes reproducible when researchers provide: 1. The data used 2. The analysis code
But this alone is often not enough‚Ä¶

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.4 Beyond Code and Data
Remaining challenges:

Which code file on which data in which order?
Software version differences
Operating system dependencies
Package version conflicts

Educational research: Often multi-step procedures with various software packages

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.5 The Reproducibility Spectrum
Not reproducible ‚Üê‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Üí Gold standard

Publication only
Publication + Code
Publication + Code and Data
Linked, executable code and data
Isolated computational environment (Docker, Binder, Quarto-live)

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.6 Literate Programming: The Key
Concept by Knuth (1984): - Interweaving natural language and code - Human-readable documentation - Code, output, and narrative in one document
Modern implementation: - Quarto - R Markdown - Jupyter Notebooks

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.7 Example: Quarto Document
Left side: Markdown + Code blocks
Right side: Rendered document

Direct traceability from text to computation
Every coefficient traceable to its calculation
Automatic documentation of analytical decisions
Output in .docx, .pdf, .html, and more

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.8 Benefits of Reproducible Reporting
For science: - Error detection by reviewers and readers - Learning from methodological details - Building on previous work
For you: - Better organized workflow - Easier to revise analyses - Documented decisions for future reference - Facilitates collaboration

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.9 Computational Reproducibility
Problem: Different software versions, operating systems
Solutions:

Basic: Provide code + data + session info
Better: Use package management (renv, conda)
Best: Containerization (Docker) or web-based execution (Quarto-live)

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
3.10 Quarto-Live: Full Reproducibility
Three lines of code change:
format: live-html
engine: knitr
Result: - Completely isolated computational environment - Accessible via browser - Executable via WebAssembly - No software installation needed - No version conflicts possible

title: 2¬† Slides
text: 4.1 Reproducibility Requires Access

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.2 Reproducibility Enables Cumulative Science
Science is fundamentally cumulative (Merton 1973):

Verification: Can we reproduce the finding?
Extension: Can we build on this work?
Integration: Can we combine multiple studies?

Each step requires: - Access to materials - Understanding of methods - Ability to reuse data and code

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.3 The Cost of Non-Reproducibility
Artner et al.¬†(2021) reproduction study: - Attempted to reproduce 232 statistical claims from 46 articles - Investment: 280 person-days of work - Success rate: Only 70%
Their conclusion: ‚ÄúVagueness makes assessing reproducibility a nightmare‚Äù
The problem: Inadequate documentation and data management

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.4 FAIR as Systematic Solution
FAIR Principles provide structure for: - Making research products discoverable - Ensuring long-term accessibility - Enabling technical compatibility - Supporting informed reuse
Not just ‚Äúmaking data available‚Äù but making it systematically reusable

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.5 From Reproducible to Reusable
Reproducible reporting solves one problem: - ‚ÄúCan I recreate your results with your data and code?‚Äù
But another problem remains: - ‚ÄúCan I actually find and access your data and code?‚Äù - ‚ÄúCan I understand what your data contains?‚Äù - ‚ÄúCan I legally and practically reuse your materials?‚Äù
‚Üí FAIR principles address these questions

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.6 Why FAIR Matters for Reproducibility
Real examples of reproducibility barriers:

Stimulus materials posted but copyright unclear ‚Üí Cannot reuse
Data available but no codebook ‚Üí Cannot understand variables
Referenced data links broken ‚Üí Cannot access
Authors left institution ‚Üí Cannot locate materials

Availability alone ‚â† Reproducibility

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.7 FAIR Principles

Findable
Accessible
Interoperable
Reusable

Framework for systematic practices that enable reuse

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.8 FAIR ‚â† Open

FAIR does not necessarily mean ‚Äúfreely accessible‚Äù
Particularly relevant for vulnerable populations
Metadata remain publicly accessible
Access path transparently documented

Principle: ‚ÄúAs open as possible, as closed as necessary‚Äù

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.9 Empirical Evidence for FAIR
Health research (Mart√≠nez-Garc√≠a et al.¬†2023): - 56.6% time savings in research data management - Monthly savings: ‚Ç¨16,800
Reproducibility study (Artner et al.¬†2021): - 232 statistical claims from 46 articles - 280 person-days of work - Only 70% successfully reproduced

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.10 F - Findable
Components:

Persistent, unique identifiers (DOIs)
Rich metadata
Indexing in searchable databases

Repositories: - Zenodo.org - OSF.io - Research data centers (e.g., Verbund FDB)

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.11 A - Accessible
Gradations:

Freely available research products
Controlled access (private repositories)
Regulated access via research data centers

Important: Transparent documentation of access path

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.12 I - Interoperable
Use of standardized, open formats:

Data: CSV with codebook, labeled .Rdata
Code: R, Python (not MPlus, STATA)
Avoiding proprietary software

Alternative open-source software: - Jamovi, JASP (instead of SPSS)

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.13 R - Reusable
Comprehensive documentation:

Codebooks for each variable
README files
Terms of use and licensing information (CC0, CC-BY, CC-BY-SA)
Research context and framework
Data quality issues

Standards: PSYCH-DS for psychological data

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.14 FAIR in Educational Research
Good examples: - National Educational Panel Study (NEPS) - PISA - PIRLS
Challenge: Scalable approaches for smaller projects with limited resources

title: 2¬† Slides
text: 4.15 Frequently Asked Questions

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.16 ‚ÄúReproducibility sounds time-consuming‚Äù
Answer:
Initial investment: Yes, there‚Äôs a learning curve
Long-term benefits: - Faster revisions (code is already there) - Easier collaboration (others can understand your work) - Better organized workflow - More citations and trust
Think incremental: Start small, improve gradually

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.17 ‚ÄúMy code is messy and embarrassing‚Äù
Answer:
The paradox of open code: 1. Knowing others will see it ‚Üí You write better code 2. Better code ‚Üí Less error-prone, better documented 3. Better documentation ‚Üí Others can learn from it
Perfect is the enemy of good: Imperfect but documented code > No code at all

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.18 ‚ÄúWhat about proprietary/sensitive data?‚Äù
Answer:
FAIR ‚â† Open: - Metadata can be public even if data isn‚Äôt - Controlled access is still FAIR - Document access procedures transparently
For educational research: - ‚ÄúAs open as possible, as closed as necessary‚Äù - Research data centers provide secure solutions - Synthetic data for methods illustration

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.19 ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be scooped!‚Äù
Answer:
Your advantages persist: - Deep knowledge of your data and design - First-mover advantage in publication - Invitations to collaborate on reuse
Reframing: - Reuse = validation of your work - Citations from secondary analyses - Broader impact of your research
Science as common good: Collective progress benefits everyone

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.20 Conclusion
Reproducibility is not optional‚Äîit‚Äôs core to science: - Verification of findings - Error detection and correction - Cumulative knowledge building
Two practical approaches:

Reproducible Reporting ‚Üí Document your complete workflow
FAIR Data Management ‚Üí Enable systematic reuse

Result: Stronger, more credible, more impactful research

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.21 Take-Home Message
Reproducibility means:

Publishing isn‚Äôt complete without data and code
Documentation is as important as analysis
FAIR principles make reuse systematic, not accidental

Start today: - Try literate programming for your next analysis - Deposit your next dataset with a DOI - Document one more step than you did last time
Perfect is the enemy of good‚Äîbegin somewhere! üí™

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.22 Thank You for Your Attention!
Questions?

title: 2¬† Slides
text:
4.23 Key References

Artner et al.¬†(2021). The reproducibility of statistical results in psychological research. Psychological Methods.
Peng (2011). Reproducible research in computing science. Science.
Wilkinson et al.¬†(2016). The FAIR Guiding Principles. Scientific Data.
Hardwicke et al.¬†(2018, 2021). Data availability and analytic reproducibility studies. Royal Society Open Science.

Complete reference list available in the paper.

title: reproduce2
section: 1.1 Low Hanging Fruits to Increase the Reproducibility of Your Research
text:
1.1 Low Hanging Fruits to Increase the Reproducibility of Your Research

1.1.1 Abstract
Reproducibility, i.e.¬†the ability to recreate reported results using the same data and analysis, constitutes a core principle of scientific inquiry, enabling the verification, error detection, and cumulative advancement of knowledge. What sounds self-evident stands in stark contrast to current practice: educational research faces persistent reproducibility challenges when essential research materials remain inaccessible or inadequately documented. This methods chat addresses reproducibility through two interconnected practices: reproducible reporting and FAIR management of materials. Reproducible reporting, implemented through literate programming approaches like Quarto (or jamovi/ JASP as an alternative), enables researchers to document their complete analytical workflow‚Äîfrom raw data through final results‚Äîin human-readable and executable formats. FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) establish systematic standards for research management that facilitate long-term reuse by both human researchers and computational systems. Together, these practices transform reproducibility from an aspirational ideal into a concrete, implementable standard. The methods chat discusses low hanging fruits for implementation, addresses common concerns about resource constraints and competitive pressures, and demonstrates how reproducible practices strengthen rather than burden the research process in educational science.
